reviewText:
Absolutely hold off spending a penny on this game until they post a patch fixing this awful sound bug.  The sound and speech vanishes making it impossible to hear what's going on around you,  and the subtitles appear for a microsecond, making it impossible to listen to NPC chatter that way.

Also

1) Vertical mouse is so much slower than horizontal mouse.  Gives me carpel trying to look up and down almost
2) Nothing like HR.  Inventory is gone.  A magic store that follows you that you can buy stuff from at any moment.
3) Can't throw objects at people as a weapon
4) Bodys vanish into a pile of pixel dust a few seconds after they fall.
5) Unable to customise the keyboard hotkeys. You must play it THEIR way.
6) When firing a weapon, the game does this weird zoom/in zoom/out silliness. Almost like your sniper scope is kicking in for a moment when each shot fired.
7) One miserable universal saveslot.  I did a quicksave and goofed around to try out some mechanics. I didnt realise autosave was on in the settings and it overwrote my quicksave.
8) Gigantic consolitis style UI elements you cant change.

You MIGHT get some enjoyment from it if you can get past all that, as even a watered down Deus Ex HR type DLC is better than half the games out there, but the sound bug is a complete game stopper.

reviewText:
Its hard to believe all the hate this game is receiving (although the latest patch fixed a lot I hear, like saving.) Let me start by saying that this isnt a fully fledged Deus Ex game, the design solely considered use on tablets and phones. Why bother coding advanced features (as seen in HR) when iOS devices of 2013 cant run them? This port is just to expand the audience slightly. Its not the greatest port as there are still some slight control issues and not being able to jump feels wierd but given its orignal design intentions there is nothing too obtrusive, think of it as Deus Ex: Lite.

The art style is the same as HR but the graphics quality is rather poor. The world certainly has the same feel as HR but its not nearly as detailed. Combat is a wee bit clunky too. The story is standard Deus Ex affair (meaning good), it focuses on the aug mercenaries that made up the boss fights in HR. Its not a perfect story though as I sometimes felt the characters had no motive to do what they were doing and the game is actually only the first part of an episodic series (no word on future installments though). Voice acting and music is very much up to par (minus the robot woman in the tutorial.) .

Ultimately what Im saying is that you shouldnt be expecting a game of the same standards as HR. Its Deus Ex: Lite and that is also reflected in the price. I got it on sale and I dont regret it.

reviewText:
Deus Ex: The Fall is a flawed game.

There is no getting around the fact that this game was built for mobile first. The game takes what made Deus Ex: Human Revolution great and butchers it, however Deus Ex: HR is an amazing game, so even the butchered remains of it manage to provide some fun.

There is nothing that this game does better than Deus Ex: HR, I still managed to enjoy it because I took it for what it is. A simplistic, short mobile port with a barely passable story.

It is hard to recommend this game, but I still will, simply because if you go past the comparison with Deus Ex: HR, then you just might find an average game capable of generating enough interest to keep you playing thorugh its 3-4 hour long campaign.

6 / 10

reviewText:
Has the visuals of the Deus Ex released in 2000 with the mechanics (sorta) of Deus Ex: Human Revolution. If Human Revolution was a fine aged Whiskey, this game is... an O'Douls.

No, but really. Just like in HR, this game has: a high-rise level, a massive ship level, a night club, a slum area with frag mines, helicopter guarded by robots, female helicopter pilot, conspiracies. Reused animations and music but super low-res textures. This is very much like a slice of HR, but at lower production value.

All quests in 90min, or up to 6 hours if you want to search every trash bin.

reviewText:
Sure, after DXHR this comes as a bit of a disappointment, but does that make it a bad game? IMHO: no!

The price for this game is the price you would expect for a DLC, the same goes for the length of the game. It is still a pretty nice story in the Deus Ex universe. The fact that the game was designed for iCrap at first sure brings a lot of drawbacks. Mainly technical and graphically. There are some glitches and some downsides but the game still plays along nicely. Sure the cam goes outside of the level sometimes and takedown-movies don't match what actually happens (body end up somewhere else etc.) but usually these glitches are just a bit annoying at worst but don't destroy the game for me. Surely not for the few bucks it cost. They actually made the augmentation-tree better.

For me the biggest negative point is that the game ends in a Cliffhanger to be continued" but they never continued it. I actually would like a sequel to this game very much
date: but corrected for the flaws in this version. (ie: not developed for mobile in the first place). I hope they still find a satisfying end to this story in DXMD which looks as awesome as DXHR was."

reviewText: This game is truly amazing. They really kept the open levels of HR, with very few loading screens, and I love the way that you can move the bodies around, in fact I love that they stay in place and don't just disappear. The game is so responsive: it does exactly what you tell it to, allowing for some complex jumping physics. The gunplay feels so great as well. The recoil is very realistic. The game also does a good job with rebindable keys and an FOV slider, as well as colourblind options, and it even has reasonable mouse sensitivity options. The tutorial blows my mind: it does a really good job of explaining what to do and never gets in the way of gameplay, and I love the way that it is possible to buy stuff during missions away from any shops: it really helps to keep me immersed in the game's interesting and fleshed-out world, with good-looking environments that are fully 3D rendered. A stunning return to form from Eidos Montreal and a real contender for the best Deus Ex game, in fact it may even be my favourite game of this year, thanks to the interesting combat system, good AI, and varied environments.\n\nIn all seriousness though, the game is broken. You should be paid to play this. Even free is too much.

reviewText:
I acutally really like this game! Its really good, but it does have some major problems!

It is a mobile port, so the graphics aren't completely up to par, but its about gameplay, not graphics. (IMO)
The gameplay is fun, I enjoyed it, but it does get a bit repetitive... usually you get a mission. Go to Point A kill some AI, come back to Point B. But, you may like that as I did. It has some VERY GOOD easter eggs for the hunters out there! I completed this game and was very satisfied that I got the original Deus Ex GOTY Edition as well! So, if you want to give the Deus Ex series a try, this is a great experience. This feels more like a DLC, rather then a game, but time to get to the glitches...

GLITCHES: Sometimes my mouse would disappear, which made me reload saves MULTIPLE times, but it also is clearly made for touch control, sometimes it took like 5 clicks to respond to the on-screen menus.

VERDICT: This is a very good, DLC-like demo for the people who want to give the series a try.

reviewText:
The other day, in preparation for the eventual release of Deus Ex: Mankind Divide, I completed my fifth playthrough of Human Revolution. Once I was finished, I noticed that, amidst various other unplayed games in my Steam library, there sat my copy of Deus Ex: The Fall which I realized I had not played. I quickly Googled the title and on the Wikipedia page, found a few choice comments from reviewers:

Don’t be fooled by the black-andgold screenshots and the familiar interface: this is not the Deus Ex you know and love. It’s a bad cover version, and truly one of the worst PC ports I’ve played in some time, and I’ve played Deadly Premonition. I definitely didn’t ask for this. -Andy Kelly (PC Gamer)
The controls are another culprit here; they are clunky and unresponsive in ways that a keyboard and mouse never should be. Menu buttons routinely fail to respond to repeated mouse clicks. -Daniel Hindes (Gamespot)
-----------------------------
Read online at http://www.petersaysstuff.com/2015/06/why-everyone-is-wrong-about-deus-ex-the-fall/
-----------------------------
After reading the comments, I decided to play it. After completing the game (yes, I did search every nook and crany) I’m here to tell you one thing: all those negative reviews are wrong. While not Human Revolution quality, Deus Ex: The Fall was, for a game ported from mobile devices in a short time-span, very solid.

Plot
Deus Ex: The Fall tells the story of Ben Saxon, a British soldier who’s squad died in a sabotaged mission and who was recruited into the Tyrants (Jaron Namir‘s gang of baddies that you end up fighting in Human Revolution), and Anna Kelso, an enigmatic former US Secret Service agent who survives a massacre and, in searching for the killers, loses her job and is on the run from the Tyrants. Saxon and Kelso, on the run from the Tyrants, are hiding out in a safehouse when the effects of the 2027 neuropozyne (Nu-Poz) shortage become too much and Saxon must find more Nu-Poz for him and Kelso. Along the way, Saxon finds that there is an alternative to Nu-Poz: Riezene. Riezene appears to function just as well, but hasn’t been approved yet. During Saxon’s investigation, he is required to complete various quests from a doctor at a local LIMB clinic to find out how the Riezene is getting on the streets. Saxon finds out that the company developing Riezene, Zaaphire Biotech, is leaking the drug an the victims from overdoses and “street trials” are sold to Belltower. After witnessing the assassination of a WHO investigator by Saxon’s supposedly dead squadmate, Sam Duarte, he bugs out and meets up with rouge Belltower VTOL pilot Alex Vega. After clearing her takeoff, they leave Panama City and head to Zaaphire Biotech’s headquarters in Australia while Kelso hides and helps from afar.

The game ends with Duarte and Jaron Namir apologizing to Bob Page for failing to kill Saxon and Kelso. Duarte vows to kill the rogue Tyrant before he can cause any more trouble. The screen then cuts to a “To be continued” card, hinting at another game starring the couple. (x)

Pros and Cons
I played the game for a solid 5 hours; not as much as some, but more than others. After my game play, I have compiled the following list of pros and cons…we’ll start with cons first.

Cons:

Sub-par combat mechanics — can’t aim down sights, limited weapon choice, when in cover can’t draw weapon without firing, etc.
Not optimized for PC — terrible character models, can’t jump, taking cover is a pain, no difficulty setting, reload animations are laughable, etc.
Glitches — falling through the floor into the abyss, takedowns place NPCs in walls where they can’t be accessed, etc.
Most of the mechanics — hacking is terrible, AI is predictable, etc.
Pros:

Story line parallels Human Revolution’s, story stays engaging, questions remain and compartmentalization of knowledge stays true to DX’s history, etc. (More on this later)
Character development and interaction is nuanced and waiting to be fleshed out in a sequel
Atmosphere
I’m sure there are others, but I wanted to make a relatively short list because, let’s all agree, the mechanics are very sub-par and I won’t dispute that. I, however, want to focus on the mechanics being solid for a quick port as well as the engaging storyline.
Why I Can Deal With The Mechanics
Deus Ex: The Fall was originally released for iOS and Android before making its way to the PC. This meant that the controls were programmed for the god-awful “console” that is the iPhone. After that, they were slightly tweaked for Android, but could largely remain unchanged. Following that, the game was rush-released for the PC giving very little time for extensive overhaul. How can I tell this? The iOS release was on 7/11/13. The Android release was 6 months later on 1/22/14…and the PC release was not even 2 months later when it became available on 3/18/14! The developers had half a year to optimize the game for Android and then less than 2 months to change everything for the PC release.

The timeframe alone doesn’t excuse the mechanics, but it does make me sympathetic and with the strong story, I am confident in saying that the quick port was solid for what it was. It was never meant to be a Human Revolution; most likely it was a side project by the developers that turned into a fun game.

Story
This is where I think the game really excels and where I am willing to say that I want a sequel. The story leaves us with questions that need answers. Why is Zaaphire leaking the drug? What is Belltower doing with the victims? How did Sam survive the ambush? Was Sam a part of the Tyrants before the ambush? Why do the Tyrants report to Bob Page? How does the Nu-Poz shortage and Saxon’s rampage affect the canon of Human Revolution? What happens to Kelso? Where does Vega go? I could keep going, but I’m sure you get the idea.

The point is, The Fall is akin to the first Detroit visit in Human Revolution — the player is left with questions that are slowly answered in coming levels — the issue, however, is where Human Revolution continued, The Fall has died.

I say, make a sequel to The Fall and release it between now and when Mankind Divided comes out! That will satisfy fans and keep the buzz alive. Remember, you #cantkillprogress!

reviewText:
Positives first.

The game is very familiar with DX:HR which means if you like that game you'll like the playstyle in this one too, I love when subs are turned on by default like here and the music is again top notch. Spotted only three really not important bugs two mobs disappeared on reload, sometimes you can't loot a hostile after takedown when he is dropped inside a wall or whatnot, you won't get an questing achievement if you warn Alvarez since it counts as quest failed while it shouldn't since after you get a reward from him you can still grab his datapad.
And that's… It.


Negatives?

1. Bloody Facebook integration. If I wanted to play Candy Crush on Facebook, I'd play Candy Crush on Facebook. Or Pet Society. Do you hear Square Enix? If you want to sell Facebook games, sell them on Facebook, not on Steam!

2. Main menu option of More content. Hello SquareE, I'm not buying DLC! Sell it to your mother. Besides I got almost every skill unlocked, what could I possibly do in DLC?

3. While I'm not graphics ♥♥♥♥♥, Icarus animation is a dissapointment and since you can't climblike in DX:HR, that skill is practically useless and you see it only in two cutscenes. Lame! Yes, this means level design also got hurt and is not nearly as good as in DX:HR.

4. The game on me was 9 hours long - explored everything, killed nothing and left no stone unturned. No, it's not I'm complaining on the total playtime, for only 10€ it's okay. However, once you finish it, instead of THE END, it says: TO BE CONTINUED. And not a single thing open in the story got resolved. Did I mention I'm not buying DLC?


Can't put 1 because it's polished and there is some fun to have with here, but can't be generous either:
2/10

ME3 perhaps didn't have a satisfying" ending but at least it had one. This game doesn't have anything even close to an ending but is an intro to another milking DLC:The Game and as such is a scam.
Guys

reviewText: I'm in the extreme minority here, but I actually enjoyed this game for what it is.  I find playing with a touch screen unbearable so I was happy to see this show up on Steam.  It's basically a stripped down HR originally made for portable devices and as such has some notable sacrifices compared to HR.  The AI is bad, the controls can be clunky and the visuals are below average.  That said, the visuals are very similar in art style to HR and IMO get the job done just fine.  The game includes a single hub roughly the size of one from HR.  If you enjoyed the hacking, stealth and story telling from HR then you may very well enjoy this too.  The combat is mediocre at best but I found the story surprisingly good.  The voice acting is adequate although not top tier by any stretch.  The game took me approximately 4.5 hours to play through which includes some but not all side quests.  My biggest complaints don't really have to deal with the core game itself and more its port to PC.  There's really no excuse for no key rebinding, regardless of being a mobile port.  The most annoying thing is the how unresponsive mouse clicks can be for the UI.  I'd be nice if you could adjust the FOV, but the default is resonable in 16:9.  Since I never played the mobile release I was happy just to see it available on PC.  Considering its origins, I think it's pretty decent.  I don't know what some people expected out of a $10 mobile port (that comes with a free $7 game).  If you're a DX fan and don't have ridiculous expectations you might have some fun with this.  For $10 I think it was easily worth it for 5 or so hours of game time.  I'd give it a 6/10 as a DX fan.

reviewText: I feel like this game would be awesome if I were playing it on a phone or tablet, but it doesn't hold up as well on a PC. It captures a lot of the experience of Human Revolution, but what would be entirely justified and minor compromises on mobile become glaring flaws on PC. It's playable, the story is solid, and I haven't encountered any of the game-breaking bugs described by other reviews, but when compared to the last entry it just feels watered down. It's deffinitely worth playing if you get it as part of a package, especially if you enjoy the storytelling of it's predecessors or have a lower-end computer you play some steam games on, but I wouldn't buy it on it's own, at least not on this platform.

reviewText: If you are a true Deus Ex fan you should play this game. It has its faults certainly and I shall get the negative parts out of the way first before stating why I believe this game should be played. For starters it is clearly a port from a phone. The controls feel a bit off and it doesn't look any where near as good as a game relelased on PC in 2014 should look. There are jarring glitches such as when you do a melee takedown on someone whilst you are in cover and suddenly you are two metres from the corner to perform the cinematic takedown. The uncertainity of whether the AI will spot you, sometines you walk right in front without them noticing yet other times you are across the room with them facing in the other direction and they swing around shooting at you. There are optional micro transactions but they are certainly not required to play at all (I built my character exactly as I wanted to no problem) so I don't see them as an issue.\nNow to list the redeeming qualities: it feels like a Deus Ex game. What I mean is the story, setting and protaganist all certainly feel like they are part of that universe. It's dialogue and the story itself are well written, the characters are engaging. *Slight spoiler alert* I wanted to know what happens next when the game finished to see where the story went next as well as as the next location was being heavily hinted at being Australia, a place I haven't explored in video game form (even though it would be a futuristic one of course).\nAll in all I believe you should play this game if you enjoy the world of Deus Ex and want to explore another part of it. Just make sure you get it when it's on sale.

reviewText: I've played through Deus Ex: Human Revolution when it came out. I enjoyed that game. Going through this game. It felt very much the same. It has the same feel and the amount of places you can go and the stuff you can do. I really enjoyed the amount of work put into this. I highly recommend it if you enjoyed the Deus Ex series. It felt like a homage to the older games. It's a bit short but its one of the few games I really liked playing through. It was quite fun. There is definitely a lot of story in it as well. I'd buy more if they came out with the DLC to extend the story a bit. If they could make the game as long as the first portion of it is. I'd be very much happy. Anywho, that's all I can say. The controls take time getting used to but they don't really hinder the game that much. So all those reviews are from hardcore gamers who complain about all those really small things. I noticed some bugs but before you stop playing. Just wait and fiddle around with the controls and you'll eventually unstuck. That only happened to me during the prologue right before the laser beam thing that you gotta walk through. You have to set your ability to the quickslot via holding Right Bumper and setting it and then using it. (It took me time since it doesnt' mention how to slot it in quickslot). Great game, It was worth my money. Oh, the game overall took me roughly 8 hours (just by walking around and exploring amongst doing the missions and side quests). I might also add, only do one side quest at a time. I'm honestly certain if you take on a new mission. It cancels out the first side quest you've started.

reviewText:
Let me be frank. This is not a PC game, this is a port of a mobile game to the desktop, a fact that is very easy to miss.

Do not expect much. It's good for a mobile game, but for a desktop one... let's just say it passes the time.

It has a story, which is an achievement in itself, mobile games being what they are. This story is actually worth some mention, as it goes in parallel to the main DEHR plot and is pretty interesting< covering topics missing from the original game.

But it is UNFINISHED. What you get is actually episode 1. And I don't suppose we'll be getting the whole story anytime soon, if at all.

Still, the graphics are OK if you are not picky (I discovered that I am not), the combat system is OK if somewhat unbalanced (top-tier weapons do not pack enough punch), and it can give you some OK hours of gameplay (around 8 if you are thorough).

Bottom line? If you played DEHR and liked its storyline - wait for a sale and buy The Fall. You'll like it.

Another addition I've also enjoyed is the weapon skins you can buy, a spetnaz rilfe from the Deus Ex HR gives it uniqe variety along with the other attachments and features.
The maps were not disappointing for me, I enjoyed looking around finding hidden areas and secrets, hacking safes and rooms to loot, making your own choice with what you say to others.
Again, it's just a port from a moblie but is pretty detailed for what it is, if you're a Deus Ex fan then by all means; get this game and by also where it all started by getting Deus Ex 1 game of the year.

reviewText:
Originally designed for tablets, the transistion to PC is reletively seamless. the first mission is a little dry, but after the training mission it plays similar to Deus Ex: Human Revolution. One partial to the story line, it is still fun and exciting, and in my opinion offered me everything I loved about DXHR.

One of my favorite things about this series is the emersion, which this game offers, just not nearly as in depth as DXHR. I love the cities, building, and the interior designs of the rooms you are in. The character clothing is amazing too.

Ment to follow the graphic novel of DX, A quick playthrough of the game can be done ina bout 4-6 hours, witht he promise of a continuation. I enjoyed it very much, as a huge loyal fan of the DX series. You probally get the best experience of the game on a tablet, but your not losing much via PC.

reviewText:
Despite the general consensus, I had a blast during my time in Deus Ex: The Fall, so much so that I 100% it.

This is coming from a huge fan of Deus Ex: Human Revolution. When you take this game for what it is; a game originally made for mobile devices, later ported over to PC. That doesn't necessarily harm the end product.

voteText: 3 of 12 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game seems to be getting a lot of flak, mostly because I think people have lost focus on what it’s supposed to be. It’s a port of a mobile game that continues the story from the Deus Ex novel, Icarus Effect. I don’t say all that as an excuse for it’s flaws, merely as a reference point.

The question I really want to pose to everyone is this, what made Deus Ex great? Was it the top-of-the-line Graphics?  The innovative control scheme? The Stellar Voice-acting? No, One need only play the original again to conclude that none of that is the case. Then what was it?

In my humble opinion, it is the uniqueness of the well-built world and story, coupled with the brilliant level design that are at the core of what make Deus Ex legendary, and those principles are what this game delivers on, albeit in a shorter and abruptly (though not unfitting) ending chunk.

Bugs and glitches are an different matter and I’ll cede that point, though I never really had any problems on either of my play-throughs.

Also, keep in mind that they could have just forgotten about us PC gamers, they didn’t have to port this game (Which, sadly enough, I have heard people in the PC world advocating for). But they did, and I for one relished the opportunity for another foray into a grim and dark world that I just can’t seem to get enough of.

reviewText: I bought this game knowing what it is: a port from tablets. Graphics and animation are not on par with modern PC games, but they are acceptable. Controls are clumsy in the fight, but since I play stealth, it does not matter. Quests and storyline are engaging, slowly revealing conspiracy around the new drug. Panama city serves as a hub with optional sidequests and some room for exploration. Unfortunately this is only the first act of the story and therefore it ends with To be continued...".\nAll in all I enjoyed the game and I hope the second part will be published in the future. Recommended only for die-hard fans who want to delve deeper into DE:HR world."

reviewText:
Deus EX the fall was originally designed for a touch-screen device, and in order to make a game of this style work for such a platform, it had to be dumbed down. Last time a Deus-Ex game got dumbed down (e.g. Invisible War) people complained... and that's even if the story was half passable and had some memorable scenes. No really, fans of Deus Ex don't like the game to be dumbed down an inch. We liked Deus-Ex for it's complexity.

The problem is that The Fall goes one step further in the dumbing down department, and aside from making the controls all but unplayable for the mouse and keyboard PC players (thank you quick-and-dirty porting department), there are aspects of the gameplay that are no longer present. Bodies now disappear in a yellow triangular matrix (no need to hide them), and my character simply doesn't seem to be able to jump. Either that, or I haven't discovered how to jump yet (thanks to the aforementioned terrible controls). Also I can't seem to scroll the node map in the hacking subgame. Seriously... what the...?

Really, it is that bad.

If you liked Deus Ex Human Revolution, prepare to relearn how to play the game again. If you're a fan you'll get this anyway, but you'll feel that the game is second rate even if the story fixes some of the character development that Human Revolution skipped in it's storytelling. The game is passable only because they aren't charging much for it, and thank goodness for that. Despite it's flaws the game is passable, but only just.

reviewText: Wow, I really don't understand all the hate. Granted, yes, the graphics are subpar but it's only a port from a mobile game. Keeping that in mind, I feel like they put a lot of effort into it. The environments are awesomely designed, there's a lot of places to explore and ways to do it.  There are dozens of files and funny emails to read. McMann composed a couple of new, cool songs for it. At first, I thought it was an adaptation of the book Icarus Effect, but it actually continues the story and I found myself enjoying it a whole lot! I can only hope we'll get to play as Kelso in part 2. The only complaint I have is that the fact that bodies disappear make the game a little too easy (less ways to be discovered). All in all, I loved it.\n\nI too would've preferred a reworked version for PC, but for what it is (and the reasonable price), it's fantastic.

reviewText:
Wow. I'm surprised by the negative reviews prevalent on the store page (as I write this). I am a long-time gamer who has played all of the Deus Ex games when they were originally released.

I personally found this to be a very enjoyable game, although I always play very steathily. I am not sure how this game would hold up if you took a more aggressive approach.

Stuff I liked
- Great environments
- Multiple pathways and solutions
- No crashes, solid framerate
- I actually enjoyed having the store present with you at all times. It kept you playing the fun parts of the game.

Stuff that could have been better
- Sticky buttons in the menu
- The UI is a bit strange
- Few animation frames for NPC's

When I am actually in the game playing, I am having a really good time. It definitely has the Deus Ex vibe, style, and gameplay from the HR version of the franchise.

If you like stealth, go for it. I've found it to be a good purchase.

reviewText:
Going by a purely gameplay point of view of the game the game is pretty good once you get past the tutorial levels where you have a lot more freedom.

As for graphics I wasn't expecting a whole lot there, as this is a handheld port, and handheld devices don't have a whole lot of processing power compared to desktops.

Most technical issues other than key binding can be worked around, eg, vsync for mouse sensitivity, and stereo sound for the sound bugs.

As I value gameplay over graphics in games, and the technical issues weren't extreme for me, I'd recommend the game.

reviewText:
A decent if not stellar mobile port, the controls are a bit laggy and the graphics are low res but the gameplay is good and felt like more Deus Ex HR to me. Returning to this world was nice and made me nostalgic for more of the full game, seeing skills like stealth takedowns and the stun gun brought it back to me and I found myself crouching in corners watching green triangles for the right moment to pop out again.

It is a port though, so it is short and designed for touch screens not KB/mouse. Auto aim is in full effect, if you miss with this one you are not trying at all and the 'click to use, hold to change' on the keys often had me wasting resources. A new game plus mode afterwards makes achievement hunting easy as you can easily max out on the second run through and literaly walk in and do takedowns on whole rooms of enemies.

Go in expecting a chance to play the mobile game and get a short burst of Deus Ex gaming in, and we can only hope the release on PC isn't the sign that the 'to be continued...' is now just another gaming lie.

reviewText:
Firstly, before you buy this game , be aware that it is a port from a mobile device , so do not expect the graphics, models and animations at Deus Ex: Human Revolution . If you come a little bit of distance to this product, you should not be disappointed . Beginning of the game along with the tutorial , does not encourage , but then in Panama is just better .

The game features gameplay mechanics almost identical to its older brother , or sneaking with guards , system hacking , punching through walls , etc. Levels can go just like the original in many ways including the fact that the entire game can be completed without killing even one person . The biggest differences in the game , it is primarily a mobile shop available everywhere and at any time , making it easier gameplay too much for my taste . General simplification.

Graphics although poorer compared to his older brother is pleasing to the eye and keeps the climate. Overall I would recommend , especially to fans of the universe , provided that it will approach the game from a distance .

The price is to high for one episode, buy only on sales.

Known issues that occur with me :

- Sometimes the screen does not display hacking the whole map and you have to toil hard to move the screen so that we can make a successful hack .
- Problems with the mouse sensitivity
- The game despite the fact that theoretically supports standard Xbox controllers , you can see on my computer did an exception and the controller does not work.
- Only one episode , I feel unsatisfied .


Rating 6/10



In Polish:

Po pierwsze zanim zakupisz tą grę, bądź świadom, że jest to port z urządzeń mobilnych, nie oczekuj więc  grafiki, modeli i animacji na poziomie Deus Ex: Bunt Ludzkości. Jak już to przetrawisz i podejdziesz trochę z dystansem do tego produktu, to nie powinieneś się zawieść. Początek gry wraz z samouczkiem, nie zachęca, ale potem w Panamie jest już tylko lepiej.

Gra posiada mechanikę rozgrywki niemal identyczną jak jej starszy brat, czyli skradanie z użyciem osłon,  system hackingu, przebijanie przez ściany itd. Poziomy można przejść podobnie jak w oryginale na wiele sposobów łącznie z tym, że całą grę da się ukończyć bez zabijania nawet jednej osoby. Największe różnice w rozgrywce, to przede wszystkim mobilny sklep dostępny wszędzie i w każdej chwili, co ułatwia rozgrywkę zbyt mocno jak na mój gust. Ogólne uproszczenia.

Grafika pomimo, że uboższa w stosunku do swojego starszego brata jest przyjemna dla oka i trzyma klimat. Ogólnie polecam, zwłaszcza fanom tego uniwersum, pod warunkiem, że podejdą do gry z dystansem.

Znane problemy które wystąpiły u mnie:

- Czasami ekran hakowania nie wyświetla całej mapy i trzeba się mocno namęczyć, aby przesunąć ekran tak abyśmy mogli dokonać skutecznego hakowania.
- Problemy z czułością myszy
- Gra pomimo tego, że teoretycznie obsługuje kontrolery w standardzie Xbox, na moim komputerze widać zrobiła wyjątek i kontroler nie działa.
- Tylko jeden epizod, czuję niedosyt.

Ocena 6/10

reviewText: Actually really enjoyed this. Being a mobile port it's not as good as Human Revolution: It's reduced and simplified in a lot of areas. Inventory management is gone and replaced with a strange in-game shop-inventory hybrid and many gameplay mechanics have been altered to try and remove elements of physics from them: Dead bodies disappear instead of the player having to hide them; objects like crates can not be picked up, instead they slide out of the way when interacted with, behaving like doors (special doors that require the heavy lifting); jumping has been removed and replaced with a vaulting-over-cover-system (which in my experience was the most buggy feature of the game).\n\nThe interface and controls bear the mark of the mobile platform in many places but it has largely been converted to work fluidly with a keyboard and mouse. The F1-F4 keys still activate augmentations, the number keys can still be assigned to hotkey inventory items (and augs as well actually), G still quickthrows grenades, etc. All that is obviously missing is (as said already) the jump button and the ability to aim down the sites (which makes the process of firing a scoped weapon a strange one and stands out as the one big issue of the controls for me). Menus are easily navigated with the mouse and all click and drag" elements from the mobile UI are easily navigated with the mousewheel. Even things like the ability to use keypads with the numpad and backspace key are intact in this game. The controls are unfortunately not rebindable though
recommended: though I don't think I would have changed any of them if I had the option.\n\nControls are not as fluid as Human Revolution though after half an hour I can safely say I stopped really noticing any initial clunkiness and found the game quite mechanically enjoyable. I played mostly stealth but the few firefights I engaged in were quite fun even if
hoursPlayed: again
voteText:
a bit clumsier than Human Revolution in both player control and enemy AI.

As for the story: It provides more conspiracies and betrayals as you would expect from a Deus Ex game. It's fairly typical of the series though with some rather over-exposition-y dialogue in many parts. This is also intended to be an episodic title and so this is only part of a storyline (a storyline that actually started in the Icarus Effect novel) so don't expect a conclusion here. Quite the opposite: it ends on a cliffhanger.

In almost all instances this game is basically Human Revolution in miniature with reduced functionality. It's quite sort too: It basically has the content of one hub area from Human Revolution and a similar length. How long it takes you to get through it will depend hugely on your playstyle but if you go straight from objective to objective shooting your way through you could easily finish it in one sitting. It's intended to be an episode game so hopefully more levels will be forthcoming."

reviewText:
I'd first off like to start by saying this game BARELY made it into my recommended side of things, but anyway onto the review.

Deus Ex the Fall was a phone game that DX fans whined and clamored to be on PC, and Square Enix granted their wish. The Fall is very ambitious for a phone game, boasting voice acting, decently sized areas and ok graphics on a phone. When ported the graphics didn't get upgraded much at all but to me this is fine as I've never been one to be a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥ and even consider most modern graphics more than we need these days in leu of putting the funding more towards gameplay and features. The area will of course feel small for a PC gamer but this reminds me a lot of Metal Gear Solid Peace Walker when it got ported from PSP to consoles, the areas are about equal in size. Voice acting at times gets very cheesy.

As far as gameplay goes, its very solid Deus Ex HR gameplay which is a good 95% what saves this game. All Human Revolution features are there and it has a solid system that lets one play stealth or action. Hacking apparently got on some peoples nerves in HR because they added a new item called an auto hacker, also present in HR Director's Cut, this will automatically succeed on any hack you perform though you still need a high enough hack level to initiate the hack on any given terminal. While I didn't use them myself its nice to see more options for people who really didn't care hacking to still be allowed to have fun. Take downs still feel good in this game but now the bodies just disintegrate instead of being require to stash them, which for stealth fans like me is a little lame but not enough to really be up in arms about. Even in a tiny mobile title like this they attempted to have several nooks and crannies for one to explore giving that feeling of exploration that any DX game needs to be successful.

Now onto some of the major problems which pretty much all come down to porting woes". Many people have reported problems with the game most I have not personally experienced but I did run into one or two.  The Hacking UI scrolling and mouse sensitivity do not work unless one enables vsync
date: which for many doing so makes the game run very sluggish
recommended: I was one of the few that didn't have the entire game crap out on me doing this but even I noticed a performance hit once it was on and it would get worse over extended playing periods. I also had extended playing periods due to the fact I didn't want to have a currently existing save bug that occurs near the end of the game where it'll load you up into a non-interactible world every single time
hoursPlayed: and due to the game having a single save file (another flaw with the game) will force one to format and start the game over. My last complaint but one I should have foreseen was the fact the game ends on a "To be continued" making it episodic

reviewText: First up, don't be completely turned off by the negative reviews. Yes this is a port of a mobile game, so it's been stripped down a fair bit. Lower resolution textures, some awful character animations during conversations, simplified interface, etc. It does manage to stay true to the overall feel of the superb Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Every once in a while the artwork makes up for the lower resolutions though.  It's pretty short, again probably a concession to the fact that mobile devices have very limited system resources.  The levels are smaller and while every area has at least two routes through, it's not nearly the sandbox of the other game. If you've read the tie-in book, Deus Ex: Icarus Effect you'll recognize the main characters in this story. I recommend the book. Once you accept the technical limitations of a mobile port it's actually a decent continuation of the story that lets you explore the world of Deus Ex and all the conspiracies. Is it a great game? No. But it isn't nearly as bad as people are saying either. I would recommend waiting for the next price drop during a steam sale, just because the shortness doesn't really seem to justify spending a full $10 on it.

reviewText:
This is an HONEST, no nitpicking, everything covered review.  Graphics are what you would expect from a mobile phone app turned PC port. If you go into the game expecting mind-numbingly good graphics, you'll be disappointed within the first few minutes of gameplay.  Combat is fine using mouse and keyboard, I had no issues whatsoever, aside from the occasional headshot not taking out an enemy.  About the bugs people have been experiencing...I didn't encounter any at all, so I can't really comment on them, though I almost wonder how many of those people who claimed to have extraordinairily bad bugs actually bought the game, or bought the game but used a NO CD exe so they can play without Steam.  Legitimately playing the game on your chosen platform usually will make your game play like mine did.  Smoothly with no bugs to speak of.

Music was fine for what it was, as well as the sound effects.  I rather thought that they re used some of the sound effects from DXHR, as I swear I could recognize a lot of the sounds from it.

Comparing this to DXHR and basing your opinion solely on that is dishonest and in my opinion, just plain wrong.  It is clear from most of the reviews that I read, that 90% of the reviews, compare the game to it's predecessor, most of their complaints centered around the graphical content, which in my opinion as stated above, are nice for what they are, not the best but still fine.

reviewText:
Having just finished the tutorial sections and story exposition parts of the first hour, I cannot speak for the whole game, but I felt it necessary to present my views after browsing the mostly negative Steam reviews on this game.

Yes, Deus Ex: The Fall is a mobile port. As such, it suffers from simplified gameplay, controls and mechanics, as well as voice acting and animations that cannot live up to the standards of the high-budget release that Human Revolution was.

However, it is definitely not as bad as people make it out to be. I can understand their disappointment, but this was never going to be a fully overhauled experience, but a port of the mobile version - and as such, it works.

Firstly, the game runs smoothly, and while the graphics options are limited to resolution, fullscreen/windowed mode and various degrees of Anti-Aliasing, lacking a Field of View setting, it does not look awful. Yes, you will recognize it for being a port, but it looks well enough.

What it struggles with are animations - especially during the many early cutscenes and dialogues. Characters look rather static, almost more so than in the original Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Gestures are rare, and overall the lack of life in the character models underlines the, in my opinion, biggest issue with the game: The mediocre voice acting.

Deus Ex: HR, outside of the main cast, ranged from acceptable to poor voice acting, but in The Fall, even the main characters have taken an obvious hit. Their lines are often delivered mechanically, or overdone, and don't match up with poses or expressions. What might not seem like a big issue on a smaller mobile screen quickly becomes disappointing on the bigger PC monitor and a proper sound system.
During the first few areas, you will find a bunch of audiologs, which are actually reasonably well done, however. This makes it especially odd that the story-dialogue between Ben Saxon, Jaron Namir, Anna Kelso and co feels flat.

Most sound effects I came across are directly copied from Human Revolution, so they are of reasonable quality. I have read about certain issues with sound effects or voices cutting out for some users, but have not experienced anything of the sort on my machine so far.
As for the music, I liked what I listened to up until now, with common themes from HR mixed with new tracks I might even prefer over the bigger title's soundtrack.

Now for the Gameplay; It suffers from its touchscreen origins, and there is nothing to be said otherwise. There is no jumping in the game, only contextual vaulting. No merry hopping around in The Fall. However, you get used to it easily, and the rest of the mechanics are fairly similar, if not the same, as in Human Revolution. There have been a few changes to the interface, though, which may need some getting used to.
The augmentations are pretty much the same as in the other game, as you might expect. I think Praxis Point requirements have been adjusted slightly, and the trees trimmed.
The dialogue system is still in, including the analyzer-augment - which I didn't get to use just yet, since all conversations so far were linear. Again, this is about an hour in, past the prologue sections.

The biggest change to the game would be the inventory / market. You can buy weapons, ammo, items, etc from wherever you are, provided you have the funds. This means you can stock up on cash, and then just pick and choose gear for the situation you are currently facing - got no EMP grenades to disable a robot? Spend 200 credits and you're ready to throw!
Personally, I think the idea is alright, but I would have liked to see limits to this system, or at least have it be more expensive than merchants found in the game.

For all its simplifications in the gameplay department, however, the world still feels like Deus Ex. The environment design seems quite alright, despite middle of the road textures for props. The atmosphere of HR is captured nicely, and ebooks, datalogs and emails are still all there, adding more lore to locations, characters and technology.

The game does follow up on the Deus Ex: Icarus Effect novel, but does a good enough job introducing non-readers to the characters and their motivations - though for obvious reasons, reading the novel first is recommended.

Please also be aware that The Fall was released as part one of the story, but so far, there hasn't been any word on a continuation. As far as I heard, the ending might disappoint due to a cliffhanger. Considering Square Enix/Eidos's plans for the franchise, though, this should get addressed fairly soon, with a new PC game in the works already, and James Swallow writing more stories based in the universe.
It should also encourage that a screen accessible from the main menu also made it from Mobile to PC, proclaiming that a continuation is supposedly happening, and the Pacifist achievement refers to the game as Part 1". I am hopeful for a continuation.

Should you expect a big blockbuster like Human Revolution? No
date: not at all. This neither had the budget nor the time to become as impressive. For what it is
hoursPlayed: it is a fine Spin-off to the franchise
voteText: which fans should appreciate
helpfulPercent: once they lower their expectations and demands to a reasonable level
votesHelpful: in accordance to the game's price and scope. It is a slice of Human Revolution
votesTotal: for a fifth of the launch price of said tripe A release. Considering that
votesFunny: I can't be too mad at the game."

reviewText:
Basically a mini-chunk of Deus Ex. If you love the series, and Human Revolution in particular, you will probably want to play it. It's amazing how much of a full Deus Ex experience it is despite being from a mobile platform originally. Town hub, sneaking and shooting, finding hidden items, upgrading your cybernetics, talking people into things, etc. It's all here.

That said if you're not super into the series, or if you're very sensitive to ports, you might hate this. It's obviously a tablet game ported to PC, and it plays like it. Menus are weird, there are little cut corners here and there like no jumping and some missing powers, and the whole thing just feels like a reduced version of Human Revolution. It's probably on par with Invisible War in the size of levels, but shorter.

How much you want this depends on how much you crave Deus Ex. It's not a full-fledged PC game, but it is close to a full-fledged Deus Game. Judge your time and dollars accordingly.

reviewText:
I was expecting way more of this game than I'm ready to admit.

I bought it because, hey, it's an DX game and it comes with Deus Ex GOTYE, but upon playing, everything felt really really compressed. I understand it comes from a mobile plaform, but there isn't quite the same punch walking through hubs as it had in both Deus Ex and Deus Ex: HR, the maps are too small and there are frequent load screens where there could be more seamless gameplay. The gameplay (as in, combat and sneaking) is buggy as hell too - I really miss the tension of having to hide an unconscious body before an incoming guard could spot it.

However, the lore found in PDAs, emails, ebooks and TV reports is fantastic - There's even space for strong references to characters such as Gunther Hermann and Bob Page, as well small mentions about the Sarif Industries attack and other events. Being part of the tyrants (albeit for a small part of the game) also makes for an interesting experience, and Namir remains a huge ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in this game.

Worth a shot if you're a Deus Ex fan. Skip it if you aren't familiarized with the series and buy Deus Ex: Human Revolution as an introduction.

reviewText:
I haven't encountered any of the sound bugs yet other people are complaining about.  The graphics are at the top end of iPad ports, but that's nothing to write home about.  I play it @ 1440p, at that resolution it's not too bad on the eye.  Don't expect it to play exactly like Human Revolution, it is not the same engine, not even designed for a PC.  What it IS is a decent story told in the Deus Ex universe.  The combat is a little sluggish but forgivable going from touch controls to full mouse look and keyboard controlls.  Instead of single slicks you will need to double click on the majority of options in the interface.

Don't go in with high expectations - it is not DLC or a standalone mini of the Deus Ex PC game series.  It's a pretty good Ipad game ported fairly well to PC.  Only pick this up if you're a fan or the world and the lore, it is Deus Ex lite" gameplay.

Look at it this way - it's better than another painful playthrough of Deus Ex Invisible War

reviewText:
Ok here it goes.

So this was a mobile game. A  MOBILE PHONE GAME. And now its here.

Yes there are issues, yes there are bugs, but hey guys IT WAS A MOBILE PHONE GAME PORTED TO PC.

At first I was like WHAT you CANT JUMP?~! But oh yeah it was a mobile game.

I think that it is an impressive port. It has a great atmosphere about it that reminds me much of Deus Ex more so than HR.

I look down and all I see are people whining about how its no HR or its buggy and laggy. Thats too be expected with any game; look at TW: ROME 2.

The more I play this the more I like it. Tried break-necking it all the way through, but to no avail.
But I am enjoying it thus far.

Any more insight to the universe of Deus Ex is fine by me no matter how buggy, I just love this universe, plus did not ANYONE notice who's voice it is in the beginning....hmmm just like Deus Ex....*sigh of comfort*

So yes I would recommend this game, but at the same time I would give a warning/forward at the beginning of my recommendation...oh wait should I have done that?

AS FOLLOWS: This was a mobile game ported to PC, it has meh meh graphics, it can be buggy, it makes up for that with the story and dialogue/music. If you're a hardcore fan of the Deus Ex universe and not just HR please check this out. Let the developers see we're fiending for me GIVE US MOAR.

7.5/10

reviewText:
I only recommend this to the most lore die-hard of fans. Yes, it's a phone game and there are terrible textures and poor mechanics, but I felt a blinding nostalgia for the story and honestly had fun that also brought up a second wind to play the original. Is it worth ten dollars for a cliff hanger? Maybe, maybe not. But I've eaten terrible subway sandwiches that costed more, and those lasted less than my experience. I put in four hours and I really enjoyed the setting and characters, albeit everything was small. There are definitely going to be people who will boycott it, because it's not a sequel to Human Revolution or a perfect homage to the original, but considering how garbage Thief is, and the lack of cyberpunk games to look forward to, I'd say buy it on sale.

reviewText:
I'll go a bit against what most people said about this game... I actually enjoyed it. Sure, it looks and plays like a poorly made mobile port, the ingame store is just silly, the voice acting is probably one of the worse I've seen since the first unpatched version of Mars: War Logs, and there are quite a few bugs here and there as well, and so on and so forth...

Still, for some awkward reason, I actually enjoyed my gaming experience besides all that... If I had to say something that really bothered me, I would complain about it been too short. Maybe I`m too big of a fan of the Deus Ex franchise, but I actually enjoyed the game and thought, for the price I actually paid for it, it was well worth it. Though, truth be told, I can completely understand why people are trashing this game so much.

All in all, I actually enjoyed playing Deus Ex: The Fall

reviewText:
I was quite fond of Human revolution and because of that I did get and play The fall before on iOS and quickly binned it because the controls were not for me.

The controls on pc were, in my opinion, way better, and increased playability a lot, even though there are a few things that just felt a bit weird, especially if you're used to Human revolution and it's controls. It didn't make it unplayable, just a bit more getting used to, which brings me to the following

The downside of the game was that it was quite short. I played about 4 hours and that was all there was. Granted, it's a mobile game, but... 4 hours? I was hardly on my way to settle in with the Deus ex universe again. I might go for new game+. That's a nice feature to put in there, even if it's just for collecting and achievement purposes.

I did encounter a few weird glitches though they didn't bother me too much to distract from the fun I had playing it.

10 euro felt a bit on the high side, in hindsight after finishing it, though since I got Deus ex GOTY with it I can't really complain that much. 10 for just The fall might be too much for some unless you want all of the Deus ex lore. If it's on sale for half price (or less) it's pretty fairly priced.

reviewText: While it has its quirks it is still a good game in th series.  The complaints are mostly due to it being a mobile port and what people want would not be a port but a re-do of the game entirely.  Adding basic keyboard commands in simplistic forms was fine and I never once had a single issue with the layout provided by the game.  Sure some of the buttons were a little odd but nothing game breaking or prevents you from playing.  My only complaint in the whole game was the fact it is not mentioned on the store front page that this is in fact not a whole game but a series.  Whether additional parts will be DLC charged based or free is another matter altogether.

reviewText: The Fall is more Deus Ex.  It offers a few innovations, like freedom from the archaic old inventory system, but by and large all the other frustrations remain.  Controls are still a bit wonky: as an example, in some places you use the right stick to scroll text, in some places you use the left stick, and in some places you must use the d-pad.  And for some reason, it's not possible to jump at all in this game.   The modest asking price does however mostly succeed in excusing the game's flaws, especially since most of the problems existed in the last game.  I haven't played enough yet to speak on the length of the game, but it's pretty safe to say that anyone who enjoyed the old game will enjoy this standalone expansion.

reviewText:
I'm only just recommending this game so far.

The graphics are rather appauling for a Square Enix related title, and are no way near on par with Human Revolution.

No longer are the old TAB and ESC menu's separate but now all under ESC and split into separate menu's, one of these includes an endless shop so as long as you have the money you can buy something anything anywhere. This for me takes away the thought of should I use my energy bar now or save for later. I had to toggle the cover system to get it to how i liked, and i find that it's hard to access your inventory items that are not quick key bound. The AI is so unlike HR and doesn't make me fear for my life like HR did it's so easy to kill them and take so little damage. I did once snipe a guard right in the path of another and he didn't even blink. Bodies also dissapear once killed or knocked uncouncious.

The one thing at the moment that is going for it is the story which is currently split into parts. The game is a prequal to HR as it involves the main group (The Tyrants) led by Jaron Namir. You start off as part of his terrorist organisation and then go freelance. The world is running out of Neuropozyne and a replacement is needed for your character and his accomplace.

I'd say only get this game if it's on the cheap and you're interested in the HR prequal.

reviewText:
I recommend this game only for people that really enjoyed Deus Ex: Human Revolution and want more of that type of gameplay.

The game is short, but the core Human Revolution gameplay is still there. The maps are pretty well designed, and most of the graphics are good. Some textures are very low quality though, but on the flipside the game will run on most computers.

The story is pretty compelling, and is at least as interesting as Human Revolution's. However, the game ends on a GIGANTIC cliffhanger, and there's no sequel currently planned.

All in all, a solid buy for $7.50 or less if you want more Human Revolution. I do not regret picking this up.

reviewText:
Played for 7h straight when writing this. Deus Ex: The Fall might be better on the iOS but if you can't get enough of the DX world and if you're an 80s kid or have fond memories/still love Goldeneye 64 and Perfect Dark - or have an augmented open mind. Then the quality of this port shouldn't bother you too too much I think. Sure there's no jump button and the textures aren't superb but they're far from bad - The story, aesthetics and attention to details is still great. PROS & CONS below:

Pros
[✓] Exploration is still feeling grand and rewarding.
[✓] The story is unexpectedly captivating and for us who like to read the e-books, e-mails, etc. they're still there.
[✓] Good dialogue, augmentations, overall choices and playstyles.
[✓] Aesthetics and attention to details in the world is still great and fitting.

Cons:
[-] I've only done a stealthy playstyle (as of writing this), but the combat isn't that exciting or engaging.
[-] Same soundtrack and tracks as DX:HR pretty much (Not a huge negative but I personally associate a lot of the audio from DXHR moments and enviornments)
[-] Only one Save slot?
[-] Mediocre claustrophobic" tutorial/introduction
[-] NPC character models in both textures and "clones""

reviewText:
This is a tentative recommendation, especially given the huge amount of bad press this game got.

PLEASE NOTE: I just need to declare first that I played this after an aparrent patch that fixed a lot of the interface and control grievances people had, I got it in sale (at around 90% off the original price) and that I use a Razer Orbweaver, meaning I could customise my controls further even than that already present in the options.

Basically, this game is not as good as Human Revolution, or even the original Deus Ex. It's also a pretty poor port for the most part, there's a lot of conventions that were obviously intended for its tablet-roots, for example the store being accessible any time from the menu, and likely originally driven by microtransactions, and bodies always fading out (even when unconcious as opposed to dead).

But the story? It picks up from after the novel the Icarus Effect, and, without spoiling too much, deals with the character's reliance on the drug Neuropozene, and essentially ensuring a supply. None of the previous characters from the previous Deus Ex games have needed this, being in some way special, and it adds an interesting new angle to the Deus Ex world.

As for that world, I'd say the it mixes combat and social/story moments as well as the best moments in HR. There's defnitely an emphasis on stealth over combat, as I found fighting moments a lot more clunky than stealth. So do keep that in mind.

So if you're willing to look past its shortcomings, the few bugs and the weird tablet vestiges, The Fall's a fun way to spend a few hours and learn a bit more about the Deus Ex world.

Deus ex the fall destroys anything than made deus ex human revolution great, invisible walls, boring storyline, dull voice acting, a campaign than lasts 2-3 hours at most and they have the audacity of leaving a cliffhanger ending saying this is just part 1 they even charge a total of 10$ for a ios port game, i highly doubt they will ever make the sequel so don't bother buying the game at full price, nor during discounts, if you really want to play this wait for a  bundle, it has been already been in one.

There's a obviously intended micro transaction system where you can buy stuff like 10 praxis kits for 10k bundle, in the pc version you don't have to pay a dime but they didn't fix the prices either.
The story is about Ben Saxon an ex soldier who's squad been wiped and got recruited into the tyrants, he's probably the most gullible hero ever in a sci fi game, trying to expose the tyrants.
Even tho this game is a prequel there's no relation to the human revolution at all except the tyrants, and only two of them are voiced, but one of the only barely says 2 lines in the entire game.

reviewText:
For those not familiar with the Deus Ex series, I would suggest playing this game to gain a better understanding of the surroundings and era. But be warned- as those who are familiar with the series- this game did bring disappointment with the development.

- You lack the same fluid movement as in DEX3 so it makes for some really awkward character movement and camera jumpyness. It makes combat exceptionally difficult.

- The AI of the NPC's is 'dodgy'. Clipping through supposedly solid surfaces just to get at you or even spot you. Makes stealth and passive gameplay a lot harder.

- I'm not a person that goes on about graphics, but I'll just throw in this; it could have been done much better for being such a short game. Instead of a rushed, half-pie piece.

I am intrigued by the characters and the history of the Mercs before Human Revolution, and it backs up how much more there is in the world of Deus Ex. I take my hat off to the creativity.

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of the original DX and I enjoyed the follow up, Invisible War. Human Revolution had some good ideas and great atmosphere. This heeling title has nothing going for it.

The Stealth play is not fun: no distractions to divert your enemies; unconcious bodies automatically clear themselves away; shaving the walls and rolling between boxes is all you are expected to do.

The Guns don't measure up either: the plasma projectiles look horrendous, like they are pasted from the original doom; no arc in trajectories; the guns don't feel like they are firing; and I question terminal physics calculations that prescribe three taps from every gun.

The takedown system barely mimics Human Revolution: allowing the player to attack advancing, alerted enemies from behind cover and then returning them back to cover seems a little too forgiving; to add insult to injury you have to watch the same disjointed takedown animation over and over again.

Looting is the worst: no inventory, just a shop with counters for items you've already picked up; enemies invariably drop credits and a gun (converted to bullets); I got more from raking bins than I did from cracking safes; and I shouldn't have to shuffle around to find the 'sweet spot' to pick an item up.

The level surroundings have no depth and cheapness lingers: areas are boxily subdivided and mostly alleyways. The writing is uniform and bland. Voice acting delivery often feels cold and hurried. And who approved Robot Aunty's voice for the tutorial?


This game wasn't worth the very low sale price.

reviewText:
When Porting goes BAD

I really love Deus Ex series, and this game let me down, it's a bad pc porting of a game made for portable devices.
If you look at it for the graphics it's plain bad, NPC faces are worse than the one in TES Oblivion.
The story, mechanics and the characters are reclicled: nightshade disco vs hive disco, the female characters that pilot the VTOL are almost the same, hacking it's the same and many other things.
Bad porting means that you'll struggle to use the menu, sometime it doesn't get the right click or doesnt' get the input at all.

Worst of all, it's a game that (for now) doesn't have an ending, you get a continue ad maybe in the future you'll have the ending (the game it's at least two years old for portable devices).

Save your money and don't buy this game unless you are a really strong fan of the series and you can buy it under 3€

reviewText:
I recommend it with some conditions. It's not a very good game, but I still found enough fun to be worth my time. If you consider this a higher quality fan mod (which is about the level of quality to expect here, not that it is an actual fan mod), there is some fun to be had here. Obviously, expecting this to be comparable to Human Revolutions or even the original Deus Ex will only result in dissapointment.

VOICE ACTING
The voice acting is pretty bad, but a lot better than I've seen from some fan mods that have tried to do voice acting.  The dialogue options are extremely limited, with very few opportunities for it to make a difference.

STORY
It's ok and it keeps the pace going.

GAMEPLAY
A lot of areas are streamlined, probably primarily to do it being originally a mobile game. No jumping, which I disliked, but I can see why one might cut that here. It gives the designers a lot more control over where a player can go in the game without having to design additional ways to block player movement to account for jumping. This also focuses the type of gameplay they are offering, allowing multiple ways through environments.

STEALTH
I liked that full stealth options were available, as well as guns ablazing.

HACKING
Much easier than in Human Revolutions, but plenty of things to hack and a few good opportunities to turn robots and turrets against your enemies.

GOODS
I noticed a ton of weapons available for purchase... though I never bought any. The store might be too easy to access, but it gave a lot more options than typically can be found. Everything is probably too plentiful in the game.

LEVELING
Leveling up was really quick, which was good since the game was short.

ONE SAVE + BUGS
I hate single save options. Just make sure when you save, nothing screwy is happening, though I found only a couple bugs during my playthrough.

FINAL THOUGHTS
If anything, the game is too easy, but I still found it fun and I'm interested in seeing where things might go next, if they still planned on making another one. It's a nice diversion, as long as you don't expect much from it. Buy it on sale, if interested, and you should be good.

Just avoid this. The scraps of story it offers aren't sufficient to redeem it to the real DX fans.

reviewText:
This game is proof that history repeats itself.

The original Deus Ex, an excellent game which won Game of the Year, was followed by Deus Ex: Invisible War. A game that wasn't bad, but which was rushed, and which really didn't live up to the first game. The mechanics and storyline were just a little bit worse, is all.

Fast forward to Deus Ex: Human Revolution. A prequel to the original, and an absolutely FANTASTIC game. And now we have this game, The Fall. It really wasn't bad; I'm not going to give it a thumbs down by any means. Hell, I just played through it in a day. I could hardly put it down. But it just didn't live up to the standard set by Human Revolution. It felt extremely rushed (the game isn't even finished yet, more content has yet to be released for the second part), with very few mechanics changed and those that were seeming a bit clunky and off. Especially irritating was the lack of a jump (what is this, The Stanley Parable?). The plot was engaging, but the few choices the player had were essentially meaningless to the ending.

If you're a hardcore Deus Ex fan like myself, then you might as well get this game. If it's on sale, and you liked Human Revolution, you might as well get this game. If you haven't played any other Deus Ex games, don't get this game! It does not stand alone! If you're looking for something different from Human Revolution, don't get this game! If you are expecting a full-blown game, and not just a 3-hour mini-game to tide us over while the real next game in the Deus Ex series is being worked on, don't bother getting this game.

Hope this helps!

reviewText:
If you're a fan of Deus Ex Human Revolution then you'll probably like this game - it continues in the same theme and style of the original quite well. I enjoyed playing this almost as much as DE:HR.

The Fall brings a lot of the good gameplay aspects from Human Revolution, from incremental augments to weapon upgrades, stealth vs assault, lethal vs nonlethal. Weaponry and upgrades can now be purchased from the pause menu which is both useful if a little jarring. Side quests also appear, as does the free roam across the city.

IF you're a person who requires a game to be 'well made' then this is a little less for you. While it's nice that this game was made for desktop and mobile at the same time it does show through - the animations aren't as good as its predecessor, I found a lot of the sounds didn't play, and some of the controls are a little problematic. I don't want to dwell too much on the downsides, but you might run into a little bit of difficulty in places if you don't have a controller.

My biggest complaint of all is the sudden ending, the game asks if you want to travel to Australia, a quick cutscene ensues and that's it. It's not a long game (think the original Portal in terms of length) but to be fair it is priced appropriately, get it on sale and it's worth a few hours entertainment.

reviewText:
I'm not opposed to the idea behind it, a mini-series that focuses on side-characters from the novel; a sort of microcosm of Deus Ex HR's gameplay in an episodic format. The execution of this idea in The Fall leaves much to be desired, partially due to problems with the game itself, but mostly due to the pains of being an obviously rushed port.

To the devs' credit, it does hit some HR beats. You have a hub location (Panama City Slums/Boardwalk/Downtown), with plenty of storage units and gates to hack, a few side-quests (though they are gated by story progress), buildings with hackable doors and safes, man-sized vent systems to serve as alternate paths, upgrade points and PRAXIS kits, stealth takedowns, tons of goodies lying around in or on trashcans/desks/safes, and the persuasion system returns at certain points (and thankfully, the CASIE mod is not an insta-win button this time, just a way to score some extra items/info).

And that leads us to the rub. Imagine, for a moment, if there was a painting you enjoyed so much that you commissioned a different artist to make a painting with a similar style and feeling, with one stipulation: the artist can never look at the original painting, they can only use your written description. Even if the finished painting resembles the original painting's style from a distance, when placed upon closer inspection, several flaws will surface.

There are a variety of upgradable weapons, but the balance feels weird (e.g. headshots from the base pistol are not one-hit kills, which means that the silenced pistol isn't a useful stealth weapon until you apply a damage upgrade). You can still choose to go in stealthily or burst in guns blazing, but the small area sizes with few enemies makes the faster Rambo option much more viable (the Pacifist achievement is bugged, as it unlocks even if you kill people in the campaign). Plus, the AI is as dumb as a doorstop; civilians don't react if you takedown a guard right in front of them; in a firefight, guards will either stay in place or walk towards your position. There are computers to hack, but almost all of them are unlock codes for doors and safes; outside of two memorable e-mails (one being from a certain person in the novel, and another referencing FF27), it's a wasted opportunity for world-building.

The story starts off somewhat interesting (Ben's flashback to his last mission with the Tyrants), then it devolves into what's essentially busywork, as Ben Saxon puts the conspiracy-fighting on hold to go to Panama City and try to find a source of Neuropozyne for himself and Anna Kelso. Naturally, he stumbles onto a conspiracy (because conspiracies are as common as Starbucks in the world of Deus Ex). Things do get somewhat interesting again due to a twist. Unfortunately, the game doesn't go into much effort to build the characters of Ben/Anna/Janus, nor does it provide much of a look at the Tyrants, with the exception of Jaron Namir. It also doesn't give much background on these characters outside of a rough outline established by a few audio logs; leaving much of their origins in the novel.

If it were just those problems, I'd probably excuse it, but as I said before, a bevy of porting problems indicate that this was a rushed port. The UI is largely the same as the mobile version, and while I can see how it would have worked on a touchscreen, it's clunky and unintuitive with a mouse and keyboard. Switching items/grenades/weapons are mainly accomplished by holding their designated key and picking the desired item with the mouse. It pauses the game, but it feels like an unnecessary step. I guess you can use the number bar, but, unlike HR, there's no constant reminder of what each number activates. That's a problem throughout the whole UI: It doesn't generally show key or button prompts, just action prompts. You might end up checking the key bindings infographic quite often.

Then there's the graphics, which weren't scaled up for the PC release, so you'll frequently notice blurry textures, simple geometry, and many low-res character models. The only character models that are detailed decently enough are the Belltower guards, the Riot Cops, and the characters that are important to the storyline (though Ben has a dead-eyed stare when his shades aren't on). Despite the low-res graphics, I still experienced some framerate drops at random times.

There are a few other notable problems with the port; a few bugs (there's a bundle of four barrels in the drug den with a Pocket Secretary on it, I'd fall through the floor and die if I took cover on it and grabbed the PS), only one save slot (saved at area changes and quick saves; I could feasibly see someone saving in an unwinnable position), the single-mouse-button shooting controls (on the crossbow, holding LMB will aim down the scope; on other weapons, it'll just fire multiple times). Perhaps the most annoying thing is when two objects are very close to each other (e.g. credits in a netphone slot); you have your crosshair on one object (the credits) and the game activates the other object (the netphone) when you hit the use key, until you find the correct position/angle to stand at.

Oh, and as for that buggered-up recoil that you've probably seen in gifs, they've fixed that problem. Now the recoil is just a slight screen shake; the difference is immediately obvious as soon as you fire a gun.

It's a sideways-thumb kind of game (leaning heavily towards thumbs down due to the rushed-port problems); not that good, but not so terrible that I'd want to actively warn people off of it. If you got into the Humble Bundle early (back when the BTA was $5-6), then it might be worth upgrading to check it out. Not so much at the current BTA price unless HB adds some big bonuses on Tuesday.
