reviewText:
I hate to have to say it, but I agree with most of the reviews and the meta score on this one. Being a huge fan of the Deus Ex game series, especially Human Revolution, I was underwhelmed when I started and completed this game. Upon purchase I saw that the game had terrible reviews and scores however since it was on sale, I decided to buy it and play it without prejudice. With that said I was extremely disappointed and I will explain why.

At this stage of the game, patches have clearly fixed many of the problems that people have talked about. I had no issue with bugs in the short duration the game lasted. That if course is always a good thing.

Obviously coming from playing Human Revolution, I had high expectations for this game on many levels. Upon entering the start up screen, I immediately went into check graphics settings and control settings. The options were poor to say the least. I was able to change anistrophic filtering and that was about it. There really was no other say when it came to the graphics of the game. On that note, the graphics were not that big of an issue for me. I was pleased with them. Although not as good as Human Revolution, it was perfectly fine for its purposes.

Once starting the game I was interested by the story. I like were the story picked up from and how a good amount of the information could be found from in game play. Just like Human Revolution your Augs can greatly help you evaluate conversations. Unfortunately there were not many coversations to be had. Even for the short duration, there are only three or four side missions that you come across without trying extremely hard. The missions are easy and just simply involve a lot of travel between the few small levels of the small map.

That is my next issue. Travel in this game is boring! There are only five or six trully distinct locations that you must travel to in order to complete the game. An hour into the game, I felt like I was just going back and forth constantly and I was already bored enough to put the game down.

The duration of the game however is my ultimate issue. Not having read any of the comments for this game, i really was expecting another full on Deus Ex game. By the game description and the story that starts to unfold, you would expect so much more, rather than a To Be Continued. I love Deus Ex to the point where I search every single room, air duct and storage unit. Even thouroughly searching through the game, It only took me four hours to complete. i was just messing around looking around and only took that long!

Overall the Deus Ex series is amazing but this game, at this point at least, is honestly not worth it. I was extremely disappointed that I bothered with it. The only real reason to have it is to say you at least own every game in the series. Thats all it's really good for. If you do choose to buy this game, do not get your hopes up and set any expectations you have extremely low.

I really don't enjoy having to right a poor review for a game especially such as this series, but such a horrible game warrants such a review. Best of luck to anyone who does decide to play. At least you can play the game again with all your current augs and purchases but on an increased difficulty.

reviewText: I am a fan of Deus Ex ever since the first one came out. The second version Invisible War was awful, Human Revolution took back the lost ground. Now we have The Fall and on the first run it's look easily as good as HR. However I am experiencing a bug that make the game unplayable. It starts out just fine, but if you Quit and Reload the Sound Effects disappear, as well as speech - so you NEED to have the captions show up or you won't know what's going on, then other times the caption window fly by so fast you can't read them, and if there is a character speaking when this happens their speech is cut off. While the music is playing you don't get any sound effects, they return after the music loop finishes, and disappear again when it restarts. You cannot turn the music off, you can only turn it all the way down. That means it is still looping and causing the sound effects to stop. There's obviously some channel overlap going on as my Sound Card is easily able to put out multiple channels over multiple devices - through Dolby 5.1 speakers as well as a Dolby 7.1 surround headphones at the same time.\nThat said there is a work around for the sound problem all you have to do is set your sound card to Stereo and the problem is solved. It doesn't look like Square Enix is interested in providing a fix. So if you can handle that, you can play the game just fine.

reviewText:
I don't hate this game.

I bought it, at a discount, fully aware that it was an iOS port. As such, I was not surprised that the areas in the game were not as expansive and sprawling as those found in Deus Ex: Human Revolution, nor was I surprised that the graphics weren't as good as those in HR either (there is a noticeable difference in quality between character models for the protagonist and important NPCs versus background NPCs and generic enemies).

It's got a lot things in it that made HR great: atmospheric music, cool cybernetic upgrades (albeit less choices than those found in HR), multiple solutions to problems presented to the player, as well as opportunities for exploration.

Personally I found the voice acting for the main character, Ben Saxon, to be superior to that of Adam Jensen in Human Revolution, whose actor I found gave a flat performance with a voice that sounded like a cross between Keanu Reeves and Christian Bale's growly Batman voice.

Even if you're paying full price for this game, at $9.99, what you get is pretty decent, even if it is a little short at only 6 hours. This game is best played with a gamepad, like an XBox 360 controller.

reviewText:
I preordered this and got the Steam edition of DX:GOTY free. I got my money's worth.

If you're paying full price, you will not get your money's worth.

Let's start with the bad. The game is glitchy. You can't change the keyboard or mouse layout, your inventory is a terrible mix of game mechanics, you've only got about half the augmentations out of Human Revolution, the graphical design reminds one of Invisible War's summer home in the uncanny valley, and the voice acting...it's a Deus Ex game. The voice acting is no surprise.

Is there any good left to be had? Of course. This is the runt of the Deus Ex franchise, but that still gives it a solid pedigree. The core gameplay is there. The vibrant world is there. The story is a lightweight, but it's there. If you're a fan of the series, there's enough here to be worth your time.

Treat The Fall as a glorified DLC for Human Revolution, but don't put it on the same tier as The Missing Link. Put it on your wishlist and wait for the price to crash.

reviewText:
The adventure revolves around a prelogue to the Australian civil war.

However, it is quite a buggy experience and a disappointing component of the DX family. In particular you might suddenly teleport a few metres and be disoriented. The takedown sequences can involve you beating up thin air whilst the target a short space away is being torn asunder by a phantom. You can no longer jump, which felt rather frustrating, and the achievements feel present for the sake of it. The game level was very easy and I suspect you could play the entire experience without a reload.

The storyline felt disjointed - there was not much drama at all. The first trip through (and I was playing pacifist mode) took 5 hours.
It is a cheap expansion but not fun. So for a die-hard fan, it is playable and expands the universe but I would advise steering clear.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Let’s get this out of the way. Deus Ex: The Fall isn’t a very good game. There are four games in the Deus Ex franchise (Deus Ex, Deus Ex: Invisible War, Deus Ex: Human Revolution, and Deus Ex: The Fall), and while I wouldn’t say it’s as bad as invisible war, it’s definitely worse than Human Revolution. Multiple factors work against the game, let me cover a few. Since it was originally a mobile title, the devs were constrained to working with inferior hardware. The levels are much smaller than Deus Ex: Human Revolution, often requiring two or three loading points to get to a certain mission. The textures and graphics are a downgrade from its predecessor as well; you can see the constraints that were put on the game with worse hardware. You can clearly tell the interface was designed for a tablet, with mechanics as simple as a jumping being removed, the inability to change key bindings, or the remnants of in app purchases. To make matters worse, the port of the game is very poor. All sorts of issues arise if you don’t turn on vsync. The sound cuts out if you are using surround sound. Performance in general just isn’t that great.

However, there are some redeeming qualities about this game; you just have to look for them. For the most part they are able to preserve what made Human Revolution so good. The combat, stealth, and hacking mechanics are all for the most part there. The environments and atmosphere are reminiscent of Human Revolution. Furthermore we get to see more of the Deus Ex universe, with the game being a sequel to the book Deus Ex: Icarus Effect.

So should you buy this game? Maybe. Despite its many flaws, I still had fun with it.  Whether you should buy this game really depend on what you thought of Human Revolution. If you really enjoyed it, I would try The Fall. It's not a terrible game, it's just below expectations.
